Boer farmers settled in Northern Natal in 1836. This created tensions over the border with Zululand and in spite of the appointment of a boundary commission in 1878, Boer farmers continued to cross the border in search of land. A kidnapping incident provoked the outbreak of war in 1879. After initial reverses the British forces under Lord Chelmsford defeated the Zulus at Ulundi. The removal of the Zulu military threat made the Boers more willing to dispute British power in the Transvaal, and in turn led to the first Boer War of 1881.
 
Captain William Molyncaux of the Cheshire Regiment was a staff officer to Lord Chelmsford in South Africa. Injured on Lord Chelmsfordâ€™s Staff in the Kafir Wars, he was recuperating at home and heard of the disastrous battle of Isandlwana. He returned to Africa immediately - in time for the battle of Ulundi, where he fought with great bravery.
 
During the battle, a premature push was made by the cavalry against the Zulus. The Zulus responded with their traditional â€˜horns of the buffaloâ€™ tactic. Chelmsford sent Captain Molyneaux to recall the horsemen â€“ now surrounded, who then had to fight their way back into the safety of the lager (defensive circle). Lampas, Molyneauxâ€™s horse, was shot as he crossed the shelter trench, The horse somersaulted and pitched the Captain into the mud. Recovering himself at once, Captain Molyneaux put his injured horse down removed the tack and saddled up his second horse Poll Evil, returning immediately to the battle.

In September 1939 war clouds again gathered over Europe. The British Expeditionary Force (BEF) left for Belgium and France to face the German Army. The six Battalions of the Cheshire Regiment (two regular and four TA) had converted to machine gun regiments in 1938. After a phoney war, the German onslaught drove the BEF back to the beaches of Dunkirk, where they were rescued by the Royal Navy by many civilians in small boats.
Retreat and Evacuation at Dunkirk â€“ May 1940:

The 2nd, 4th and 7th Battalions were involved in Dunkirk, their carrier-borne transport, medium machine guns and radio communications were used in the attempt to control the retreat to the coast at Dunkirk. Some of the 4th Battalion who were taken prisoner suffered dreadfully in a massacre, at the hands of the SS. The main theatre of land operations became the Middle East where the British needed to protect their oil supplies. The war in Europe was at first fought largely in the air and the Battle of Britain was fought and won in 1940 to 1941 in the skies over England. Perhaps the real success though lay in securing the Atlantic Sea routes. The battle of the Atlantic was fought from a command centre in Liverpool against the German U-boats. The Second World War was more mobile than the first. The Yeomanry in the Cavalry Division fought against the Vichy French in Syria. The battalions of the Cheshires served in North Africa, in Malta â€“ in the famous siege; in Iraq, Sicily, Italy and eventually the Normandy Landings and the fight across Germany to victory. The 3rd Carabiniers served in Burma as a tank regiment and the 5th Royal Inniskilling Dragoon Guards joined with the Cheshires to fight in France and Germany. The war produced many new units like the Army Commandos, Parachute and Glider Pilot Regiments.
